name: Apples
description: Worldwide, there are more than 7,500 known varieties, 100 of which are grown commercially in the US. They all differ in shape, size, color, texture, aroma and flavor.

name: Apricots
description: Apricots only ripen on the tree. Once picked, they become softer but not more flavorful. Look for fruit that is bright with no green tinge.

name: Avocados
description: Its skin may be smooth or bumpy, bright green or black, and they can be pear-shaped, egg-shaped or spherical. An avocado is ripe when it yields to gentle pressure when squeezed.

name: Blackberries
description: Many brambles growers are not certified organic but do not spray their crops. Get as local as you can and ask the grower about their growing methods.

name: Blueberries
description: Look for firm, dry, plump blueberries with smooth skin and no shriveled or moldy bits. Pass on greenish or red ones â€” they're underripe.

name: Cabbage
description: Red and green cabbage should have a firm, tight head and feel heavy for their size, with no black or soft spots. Savoy and Napa cabbage are generally a bit looser.

name: Carrots
description: Carrots come in all shades of purple, red, white, yellow and of course, orange. If they have the greens attached, look for feathery, perky leaves with no wilting, black spots or yellowing.

name: Corn
description: Look for ears that are firm, plump and unblemished. Instead of stripping down the husks to examine, just gently squeeze cobs down the length of the ear to feel for bald spots.

name: Dairy
description: Finest cow milk around

name: Eggs
description: Organic, free-range chickens produces only the best eggs

name: Lettuce
description: There are many varieties of lettuce, from loose-leaf to those bought as a head. For all varieties, look for leaves that are intact and not wilting.

name: Mandarins
description: Color is not always a good indicator of a mandarin's ripeness, so don't hesitate to pick up one that is still a little green so long as it smells sweet.

name: Meat
description: 100%, Grass-fed, USDA Beef

name: Nectarines
description: A variety of peach with fuzzless skin, be sure to choose a fruit that has a strong perfume and is free of blemishes and bruises.

name: Oranges
description: Oranges that are still green and too hard are not yet ripe. Instead, choose an orange that has medium firmness and feels juicy when lightly squeezed.

name: Pecans
description: Pecans are oval-shaped nuts that have a rich, buttery flavor. They can range in color from tan to brown and can be purchased either in the shell or already shelled.

name: Pumpkins
description: While pumpkins come in a variety of types, sizes and colors - you should always choose a pumpkin that feels heavy for its weight and pass on those with any black or mushy spots.

name: Raspberries
description: Good raspberries should be evenly colored and intact; squished berries will quickly go bad.

name: Spinach
description: Fresh spinach leaves can be sold as loose leaves or still attached to the stem. Look for perky, evenly colored leaves with no mushy spots. Smaller leaves will be the most tender while larger leaves can be stringy in texture.

name: Strawberries
description: Bigger isn't always better when it comes to strawberries: look for berries that are glossy, fragrant and deeply colored all the way up to the stem.

name: Tomatoes
description: Tomatoes come in a dizzying array of colors and shapes, so rather than relying on color alone, look for tomatoes that are heavy and fragrant. Some scarring is normal on heirloom varieties, but avoid tomatoes with freshly torn skin.
